lexUnit.name: dwell.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: think, speak, or write at length about.

sentence.text: But these are technical considerations not to be dwelt on here .
I do n't think Norman would want it to be dwelt upon , but he deserves our making the imaginative effort to appreciate the scale of those climbs for a man with artificial legs .
Why must each separate moment of the work be dwelt upon ?
Do n't dwell only on the horrors and dreadful effects of drugs .
I may also have dwelt too long on the years between 1690 and 1730 , but this was simply because it seems to be most people 's favourite period .
We need not here dwell long on these matters .
I will not dwell much longer on conformal mapping ( this is incidentally the term most often used for describing the method ) but will give a few more examples .
The authors dwell on the conflicts of interest arising from the commercialization of genetics and biotechnology .
The coach will not dwell on his difficulties , however .
` We 've dwelt too much on disaster -- and former triumphs too .
We laugh about the whole experience now , but we do n't really like to dwell on particular moments too long .
Marketing dogma of old had it that car buyers do n't want to hear about car safety , preferring not to dwell on the possibility of being killed or injured on the road .
But it 's horrid to dwell on these things where the central effort and basic attitude is so right minded .
Dread on arriving at his own home had become an almost familiar sensation by now , but he did n't pause to dwell upon the fact .
Western artists frequently dwelt upon their private obsessions ; we see the distorted or frightening images of their dreams , nightmares and fantasies .
Like their western counterparts , they often did dwell upon the dark side of life .

That , perhaps , is one reason why Mr Clinton has dwelt particularly upon ` symbolic " politics : like making the armed forces accept gays or staffing his administration with an eye to ethnic ` balance " .
If Oliver 's fear was slightly more explicit than is common , this was merely because killing people was a concept he dwelt upon fairly frequently and with lively interest .
My result in the afternoon race was the worst of the event as I dwelt over my fate up the first beat .
She tried not to dwell on why it was that she had n't .
The CECOS surveyors tended to dwell on whether the houses were clean , well-kept and so forth .
Her mind sheered away from images she did n't want to dwell on .
